author: ricmoo
content: https://github.com/ethers-io/ethers.js/issues/1610

author: ricmoo
content: I just needed the JSON-rpc endpoint. But swapping out the explorer port solved it.

author: ricmoo
content: Also, I have a questions. I‚Äôm running into the following problem: I am following the current advice of using 2x the last base fee for the max fee and hard coding 1 gwei for the priority fee, but‚Ä¶

author: ricmoo
content: The current base fee on Calaveras is 7 **wei**. So 14 wei, is far less than the 1 gwei being hard-coded for the priority, which is failing.

author: ricmoo
content: So, what is a better way to estimate values. üôÇ

author: ricmoo
content: Should the maxfee always be the min(2*baseFee, 2 * baseFee + priorityFee)

author: ricmoo
content: This needs a ‚Äúgood‚Äù solution; I feel like some will say ‚Äúon the real network it will never be 7wei‚Äù, but we need to keep in mind there will be testnets and ilk where this can still be true. Base fee is atrociously tiny.

author: ricmoo
content: Compared to 1 gwei default priority.

author: sky.cactus
content: Priority fee != base fee.

author: ricmoo
content: I know.

author: sky.cactus
content: My recommendation for launch is `2 * baseFeePerGas + priorityFeePerGas`.

author: ricmoo
content: That means on networks with a low baseFee, the priority fee is 100‚Äôs of millions times more expensive than the base fee.

author: sky.cactus
content: And for launch I recommend `priorityFeePerGas = 2e9`, though with the new JSON-RPC endpoint being worked on you could do a tad better.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is expected and correct.

author: ricmoo
content: The priority fee is expected to dwarf the base fee?

author: sky.cactus
content: Priority fee is to offset uncle risk, which is a function of block propagation time and block reward.

author: sky.cactus
content: The two are not related to each other.

author: sky.cactus
content: In some cases, one will dwarf the other, in others it will be the other way around.

author: sky.cactus
content: One should not assume that base fee is always on the same order of magnitude as the priority fee.

author: sky.cactus
content: That is, they move completely independent of each other and they are not a function of the same inputs.

author: ricmoo
content: I agree. But the hard-coded value is making even less sense on unpopular networks. We def need a better way to approximate it.

author: sky.cactus
content: On Ropsten, a priority fee of ~1e9 is still very much correct.

author: ricmoo
content: maxFee = 1000000014 and priority fee = 1000000000 seems weird. :p

author: sky.cactus
content: On Rinkeby/Goerli things get *way* more complicated since they are proof of authority so uncle risk calculations are incredibly different.  I don't know if anyone has calculated it.

author: ricmoo
content: But ok. I‚Äôll make that the built in defaults.

author: sky.cactus
content: Why does it seem weird?

author: ricmoo
content: That would be like ordering a $3 soda from a restaurant and paying $500 million as a tip.

author: sky.cactus
content: There are *many* restaurants where the cost of the food is dwarfed by the cost of the service.  üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: It is just that in most cases they don't bill separately for the two.

author: ricmoo
content: Also, on a PoA network, uncle risk is negligible. üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, on PoA things are different but I don't think anyone has taken the time to calculate a "correct" priority fee.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, since they are just test networks I don't think anyone actually cares.  ü§∑

author: ricmoo
content: True. /)

author: ricmoo
content: üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: A $100 steak is like $5 in meat, $5 in cooking, $90 in "fancy wait staff and ambiance".

author: ricmoo
content: Yes, but I‚Äôd only leave $20 tip. üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think you should compare US tips, because they do not make economic sense.

author: ricmoo
content: Service costs should be considered rolled into the baseFee.

author: sky.cactus
content: We are trying to build an economically rational system here, not mirror an economically irrational system.  üòÑ

author: ricmoo
content: The baseFee is the cost of doing business + necessary profit to remain operating.

author: sky.cactus
content: (another reason I despise the term `tip` for priority fee, it makes people think about the problem wrong)

author: ricmoo
content: üòâ

author: ricmoo
content: Anyways. That‚Äôs why it seems weird.

author: ricmoo
content: But it‚Äôs easy to do.

author: sky.cactus
content: Base fee is not the cost of doing business.  Base fee is the market rate for blockspace.

author: sky.cactus
content: Priority fee is closer to the "cost of doing business".

author: sky.cactus
content: Given a limited resource and more demand for that resource than supply, the price goes up until supply == demand (as demand exits due to price being too high).  This is totally unrelated to operational costs, this is just a mechanism to figure out "who wants in more".

author: sky.cactus
content: Priority fee is essentially operational cost of miners (ish).

author: ricmoo
content: Also, can you point me to maths for computing a given block‚Äôs baseFee? Right now I‚Äôm using 2x getBlock(-1).baseFee, but it should probably be something more math-sound based on block(-1) baseFee and gasUsed/gasTarget (also, I didn‚Äôt see a gasTarget on the block).

author: sky.cactus
content:
```python
if INITIAL_FORK_BLOCK_NUMBER == block.number:
    expected_base_fee_per_gas = INITIAL_BASE_FEE
elif parent_gas_used == parent_gas_target:
    expected_base_fee_per_gas = parent_base_fee_per_gas
elif parent_gas_used > parent_gas_target:
    gas_used_delta = parent_gas_used - parent_gas_target
    base_fee_per_gas_delta = max(parent_base_fee_per_gas * gas_used_delta // parent_gas_target // BASE_FEE_MAX_CHANGE_DENOMINATOR, 1)
    expected_base_fee_per_gas = parent_base_fee_per_gas + base_fee_per_gas_delta
else:
    gas_used_delta = parent_gas_target - parent_gas_used
    base_fee_per_gas_delta = parent_base_fee_per_gas * gas_used_delta // parent_gas_target // BASE_FEE_MAX_CHANGE_DENOMINATOR
    expected_base_fee_per_gas = max(parent_base_fee_per_gas - base_fee_per_gas_delta, 0)
assert expected_base_fee_per_gas == block.base_fee_per_gas, 'invalid block: base fee not correct'
```

author: sky.cactus
content: (from EIP-1559)

author: sky.cactus
content: For `parent_*` you would use the `latest` block details, and the `expected_base_fee_per_gas` will be the base fee of the next block.

author: sky.cactus
content: Pragmatically, I think `2 * eth_getBlockByNumber('latest').baseFeePerGas` is very reasonable.  That `2` in there is pretty arbitrary and in most cases dwarfs the difference between `latest.baseFeePerGas` and `pending.baseFeePerGas`.

author: sky.cactus
content: `gasTarget = block.gasLimit / 2`

author: Deleted User
content: basefee seems more like a deflation tax than a market rate for blockspace :> because first of all it gets burned and second of all its determined by an algorithm. So its more of a tax than a market rate. Just my humble opinion.

author: ricmoo
content: And it has a minimum of 7? Or is that guaranteed by the maths?

author: sky.cactus
content: Just a side effect of the maths.  I recommend testing < 7 cases if you want to be thorough (like make sure it can walk up from 0) if you are implementing stuff.

author: ricmoo
content: Perfect.

author: sky.cactus
content: Specifically, the 7 minimum is a side effect of integer math rounding and can change if some of the constants change (like the rate of change).

author: sky.cactus
content: Which is why I recommend against hard coding a minimum, because then you'll have a bug if that constant changes in a future hard fork.

author: ricmoo
content: Yeah.

author: ricmoo
content: If integer rounding works, I prefer that.

author: sky.cactus
content: If it doesn't, it means you round differently than the rest of the clients.  üòÑ

author: sky.cactus
content: (round up vs round down)

author: ricmoo
content: Lol! I assume truncation. üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: "Round toward 0", which I think is synonymous with truncation?

author: ricmoo
content: But for now I may just stick with the 2x baseFee. But I‚Äôll add a comment about this.

author: ricmoo
content: Yeah.

author: sky.cactus
content: We specifically avoided negative numbers in the algorithm because apparently rounding negatives differs a lot across languages.

author: ricmoo
content: Rounding down vs. rounding towards 0. üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: (round toward 0 vs round toward negative infinity)

author: ricmoo
content: Exactly.

author: sky.cactus
content: That was something I didn't know was highly debated in math circles until this project.  üò¨

author: sky.cactus
content: Apparently, both have arguments for why they are "right".

author: ricmoo
content: Also the correct usage of underflow. Which is unrelated to overflow.

author: juanblanco
content: Maybe a silly question, but how do we calculate the exact cost of a transaction? Scenario, I want to transfer all the Ether from one account to another, without leaving crumbs. I know the base fee for the latest block is x, and I want to pay a service fee to the miners of y.

author: juanblanco
content: But we apply the 2x baseFee..

author: juanblanco
content: There is a big chance that a portion of the amount will be returned

author: sky.cactus
content: Sweeping is hard.

author: sky.cactus
content: You can force a sweep by setting maxFee and maxPriorityFee to the same value, but this basically just burns any excess money.

author: sky.cactus
content: Useful if you care about actually clearing the value from the account, not useful for maximizing the amount out.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would support someone creating an EIP for a new "sweep" transaction type specifically for dealing with this situation.

author: juanblanco
content: Yep, i thought of that, but if maxFee and maxPriorityFee are the same, how are we accounting for the baseFee? Edit: Ok I got it.. base fee will be discounted anyway from the miners fee.

author: sky.cactus
content: It isn't great, but if the person wants their account to "go to zero" that is the way to do it.  It basically says, "pay this much fee, give any leftovers to the miner".
